title: Parkinsonia
text:
Parkinsonia , also Cercidium , is a genus of <a href="flowering%20plant">flowering plant</a>s in the <a href="pea">pea</a> family, <a href="Fabaceae">Fabaceae</a>. It contains about 12 species that are native to semi-<a href="desert">desert</a> regions of <a href="Africa">Africa</a> and the <a href="Americas">Americas</a>. The name of the genus honors <a href="Kingdom%20of%20England">English</a> <a href="apothecary">apothecary</a> and botanist <a href="John%20Parkinson%20%28botanist%29">John Parkinson</a> (1567–1650).
They are large <a href="shrub">shrub</a>s or small <a href="tree">tree</a>s growing to tall, <a href="dry%20season">dry season</a> <a href="deciduous">deciduous</a>, with sparse, open, <a href="Thorns%2C%20spines%2C%20and%20prickles">thorny</a> crowns and green bark. The <a href="leaf">leaves</a> are <a href="pinnate">pinnate</a>, sometimes bipinnate, with numerous small <a href="leaflet%20%28botany%29">leaflets</a>; they are only borne for a relatively short time after rains, with much of the <a href="photosynthesis">photosynthesis</a> carried out by the green twigs and branches. The <a href="flower">flower</a>s are symmetrical or nearly so, with five yellow or white <a href="petal">petal</a>s. The <a href="fruit">fruit</a> is a <a href="legume">pod</a> containing several <a href="seed">seed</a>s.
Most American species are known by the common name of palo verde or paloverde, from the <a href="Spanish%20language">Spanish</a> words meaning "green pole" or "green stick". This name is derived from its characteristic green <a href="Trunk%20%28botany%29">trunk</a>. The palo verde (not species-specific) is the state tree of <a href="Arizona">Arizona</a>.
Ecology.
A major pollinator for "Parkinsonia" species in the southwestern United States and western Mexico is "<a href="Centris%20pallida">Centris pallida</a>", a solitary bee known as the digger or pallid bee. "C. pallida" obtains nectar and pollen from this plant to fill a brood pot so that their larvae will have food when they hatch. The nectar and pollen give its <a href="Bee%20pollen">bee bread</a> a strong orange color.
